Award.AwardTitle: Statistical learning via multivariate density estimation
Award.AbstractNarration:
The overall goal of the project is to develop methodologies of density estimation in multiple dimensions, and to develop new tools based on this methodology for selected problems in data compression, image analysis and graphical model inference. Density estimation is a fundamental problem in statistics but traditional approaches such as kernel density estimation are not well suited to handle the large multivariate data sets in current applications. The research in this project is centered on the methodology and application of multivariate density estimation. By creating effective methods for this problem, this project will also benefit many other research problems in applied statistics and machine learning where density estimation can be used as a building block for the solution, for example, image segmentation, data compression and network modeling.

Specifically, the project will address the question of how to infer a partition of the sample space that will reveal the structure of the underlying data distribution. The partition will be learned from the observed data based on a Bayesian nonparametric approach which imposes minimal assumptions on the distribution to be estimated. Efficient and scalable algorithms for such inferences will be designed for the analysis of large data sets in multiple dimensions. The theoretical properties of the estimates, such as asymptotic consistency and convergence rates, will also be investigated.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aims to develop statistical methods suitable the analysis of multi-dimensional data sets of large sample sizes. This is formulated as a problem of the estimation of a multivariate density function that characterizes the distribution of the data points in multi-dimensional space. The methods and algorithms developed in this project enable us to understand this data distribution even if it is not of falling within known families of distributions such as the multivariate normal distribution. In particular, the shape of the data density function can be non-convex, multi-modal, and not admitting any parametric representations.  

The approach taken in this project is to partition the multi-dimensional space into many hyper-rectangular regions, through a process of recursive divisions along different dimensions. Both the partitioning and the density value within each part of the partitioning, are obtained from the data via Bayesian statistical learning. The estimation methods and related Bayesian computational algorithms are studied theoretically and by simulation, to gain deeper understanding of their properties. The new estimation methods resulting from this research are implemented as user-friendly software and are made available for free use by the scientific community.

To demonstrate their practical value, the methods are applied to important scientific problems such as the analysis of the properties of single cells using multi-dimensional mass cytometry. It is expected that the methods will be useful in any application area with large, multi-dimensional data sets. Thus the results of this research are expected to have wider impact beyond statistics.
